I think it would be useful in certain cases, sort of
like "make -k" (keep going if an error is found).

Although sometimes continuing isn't helpful because
the later assertions assume the previous ones
succeeded (just like a syntax error can throw the
parser/compiler out of sync), that's not always the
case and some people like to work in a batch mode:
generate a list of problems, fix a bunch of them,
re-test, ...

This could possibly be an option to the test runner,
just like the make flag, but as someone else pointed
out you can do this via separate test methods.

--- Jason Rogers <jason.rogers@...> wrote:
> I don't have an answer for you, but I do have a
> question.  Why would you
> want to do this?  One of the strengths of the
> framework (IMHO) is the
> guidance it gives me to fix every test
> incrementally.  I am unclear on why
> you would want the test to go on.  It seems to me
> that you would end up
> biting off more than you can chew.
> 
>     > Hi,
>     > 
>     > When I run my test suite I found that each
> test stops 
>     > running after the
>     > first failed assertion. I have a number of
> assertions in 
>     > each test and I
>     > would like to know every assertion that is
> broken. I have tried to
>     > create a default TestResult inside each test
> using,
>     > 
>     > 	TestResult result = createResult();
>     > 
>     > and then adding failures to 'result' using,
>     > 
>     > 	result.addFailure(mytest, afe);
>     > 
>     > which works fine, except that no
> AssertionFailedException 
>     > gets thrown

> broken assertions.
>     > 
>     > Is there any way I can get JUnit to show all
> broken 
>     > assertions for each
>     > test and not move onto the next test when the
> first 
>     > assertion fails?
>
